Name:  ___              Unit No:   ___
 
Admission Date:  ___              Discharge Date:   ___
 
Date of Birth:  ___             Sex:   M
 
Service: MEDICINE
 
Allergies: 
Penicillins
 
Attending: ___
 
Chief Complaint:
Right intertrochanteric hip fracture
 
Major Surgical or Invasive Procedure:
___: Right hip repair with trochanteric fixation nail. 

 
History of Present Illness:
___ w/ Afib on Eliquis, CAD, HTN, RA who presents after a 
mechanical fall onto the right side. +HS, no LOC. Immediate 
onset of right hip pain and inability to ambulate. No numbness 
or paresthesias. At baseline, he ambulates with a cane. Last 
dose of Eliquis ___ AM.

TRANSFER TO MEDICINE HPI:

In brief, this patient is a ___ gentleman with CAD, Afib on 
Eliquis, hx of CVA, CKD, and RA on prednisone admitted for R 
intratrochanteric fracture from mechanical fall s/p operative 
fixation on ___, with post-operative course complicated by 
pneumonia treated with levofloxacin, a-fib with RVR, and 
delirium.  

     Medicine was consulted in on ___ due to episodes of 
atrial fibrillation with RVR to 150s. Episodes began evening of 
___. Previously heart rates were in ___ to ___. He has also 
had worsening agitation, intermittently refusing care. He 
self-removed an IV catheter earlier in evening. Per outpatient 
records, there is concern for mild-moderate dementia at baseline 
though this has not been formally evaluated, and he lived 
independently prior to current presentation. He is being 
transferred to medicine for management of recurrent episodes of 
tachycardia and delirium.  

    Upon transfer, patient feels well. Denies any pain. Reports 
being persistently short of breath, but has good appetite, PO 
intake. No specific complaints.

 
Past Medical History:
CAD/HLD/HTN
- s/p PTCA of OM-1 in ___ 
Afib
Nonsustained supraventricular tachycardia with exercise
Rheumatoid arthritis
Bronchogenic cyst
Anemia
Monoclonal gammopathy
Splenic Infarct
Basal Cell carcinoma

no history of CAD, DM

K-4.6 Cl-102 HCO3-20* AnGap-22*

___ 05:10AM BLOOD CK-MB-5 cTropnT-0.10* ___

IMAGING: 
=======
XR L Hip (___):
There is an acute impacted, comminuted intratrochanteric 
fracture through the proximal right femur.  

CT Pelvis w/o contrast ___: 
1. No evidence of discrete intramuscular hematoma.  
Intramuscular edema most pronounced in the anterolateral 
compartment is compatible with postsurgical changes.
2. Circumferential soft tissue edema, likely postsurgical.
3. No evidence of early hardware complication after repair of a 
right comminuted intertrochanteric fracture.
4. Multiple sclerotic bony lesions, most stable since ___, 
although a lesion in the L5 vertebral body and left sacrum have 
significantly increased and are new from that time, 
respectively.  These lesions have typical morphology of bone 
islands, although the degree of enlargement is atypical, 
correlation with PSA is recommended.

CXR ___
Heart size and mediastinum are stable.  There is interval 
development of large right pleural effusion, vascular congestion 
and moderate left pleural effusion.  Right lower lobe pneumonia 
cannot be excluded.

Femur AP/Lat ___
Interval internal fixation across intertrochanteric comminuted 
fracture.  Benign bone island right iliac bone.  Degenerative 
changes right hip.  Arterial calcifications.  Surgical staples.

ECHO ___
The left atrium is moderately dilated. The right atrium is 
moderately dilated. There is mild symmetric left ventricular 
hypertrophy with normal cavity size. Due to suboptimal technical 
quality, a focal wall motion abnormality cannot be fully 
excluded. Overall left ventricular systolic function is normal 
(LVEF>55%). The estimated cardiac index is normal 
(>=2.5L/min/m2). Diastolic function could not be assessed. The 
right ventricular cavity is mildly dilated with normal free wall 
contractility. The ascending aorta is mildly dilated. The number 
of aortic valve leaflets cannot be determined. The aortic valve 
leaflets are mildly thickened (?#). There is no aortic valve 
stenosis. Mild (1+) aortic regurgitation is seen. The mitral 
valve leaflets are mildly thickened. There is no mitral valve 
prolapse. Mild (1+) mitral regurgitation is seen. There is 
moderate pulmonary artery systolic hypertension. There is no 
pericardial effusion. 

IMPRESSION: Suboptimal image quality. Biatrial dilatation. Mild 
symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with preserved global 
systolic function. Mild right ventricular cavity dilatation in 
the context of at least moderate pulmonary hypertension. Mild 
aortic and mitral regurgitation. Dilated thoracic aorta. 

Compared with the prior study (images reviewed) of ___, 
pulmonary artery pressures are higher. The right ventricle is 
mildly dilated. 

CT Head ___ 
IMPRESSION:
1. No acute intracranial process.

Brief Hospital Course:
Surgery Hospital Course: 
==================

The patient presented to the emergency department and was 
evaluated by the orthopedic surgery team. The patient was found 
to have a left intertrochanteric femur fracture and was admitted 
to the orthopedic surgery service. The patient was taken to the 
operating room on ___ R TFN, which the patient tolerated well. 
For full details of the procedure please see the separately 
dictated operative report. The patient was taken from the OR to 
the PACU in stable condition and after satisfactory recovery 
from anesthesia was transferred to the floor. The patient was 
initially given IV fluids and IV pain medications, and 
progressed to a regular diet and oral medications by POD#1. The 
patient was given ___ antibiotics and anticoagulation 
per routine. The patient's home medications were continued 
throughout this hospitalization. The patient worked with ___ who 
determined that discharge to rehab was appropriate. The patient 
is weight bearing as tolerated in the right lower extremity, and 
will be continued on home  eliquis for DVT prophylaxis. The 
patient will follow up with Dr. ___ routine. 

Following surgical repair of his r. hip fracture, the patient 
was transferred to the Medicine team for further management of 
persistent AMS/delirium, atrial fibrillation with RVR, 
iatrogenic volume overload, and chronic aspiration requiring 
initiation of dobhoff feeds as detailed below:

Medicine Hospital Course:
===================

Mr. ___ is an ___ with CAD, Afib on Eliquis, CKD, and RA on 
prednisone admitted for R intratrochanteric fracture from 
mechanical fall s/p operative fixation on ___, with 
post-operative course complicated by pneumonia treated with 
levofloxacin, a-fib with RVR, and delirium. He ultimately did 
not recover from his aspiration pnuemonia and associated 
delirium and was made CMO on ___ and expired the same day.   

#Delirium: 
Mild-moderate dementia at baseline. However, independently 
functional prior to this hospitalization. Current delirium is 
likely multifactorial in setting of infection, recent surgery 
with anesthesia, pain, lack of hearing aids. Repeat CT head 
without acute intracranial abnormality (ie chronic subdural 
hematoma). Patient treated for reversible causes including 
pneumonia, but still with persistent delirium and he ultimately 
expired as above. 

#GOC: 
Multiple goals of care discussions were held during this 
admission. Patient is DNR/DNI, but family would like to pursue 
temporary trial of nutrition support to see if patient can 
recover through his current delirium. Per family, initially 
willing to do trial of dobhoff for feeds for now and trial at 
___. His mental status was not improving and he was ultimately 
made CMO. 

#Atrial fibrillation with RVR: 
Diagnosed in ___. Previously on amiodarone, Coumadin. CHADSVASC 
= 3. Now on Eliquis and metop XL 50 mg at home with baseline HRs 
in the ___. At one point during this hospitalization, 
developed persistent RVR to the 110s-150s with no response to IV 
metop 5 mg x 2. Improved with 15 mg diltiazem push to the ___. 
Stable BPs. Likely in the setting of agitation/delirium vs. 
pain. Good rate control achieved with regimen of 37.5mg metop 
tartrate q6h. Expired as above. 

#Pleural effusion/pulmonary congestion: 
Improving on most recent imaging following diuresis and 
anitibiotics. Likely secondary to iatogrenic volume overload and 
underlying PNA. Unlikely CHF, as ECHO with preserved EF. Patient 
also with recurrent episodes of aspiration in setting of 
impaired swallowing, for which he was placed on strict NPO, 
aspiration precautions, and chest ___. ___ was placed for 
enteric feedings. Expired as above. 

#Urinary rentention: 
Likely multifactorial. Suspect BPH, recent foley in OR, and 
current sedation. PVR 155 after voiding on ___. Unable to take 
tamsulosin via ___. Expired as above. 

#Aspiration risk/poor swallowing: 
Failed S&S, Dobhoff in place for trial of tube feeds. 

# Right IT femur fracture: 
As detailed above, patient underwent OR fixation on ___.  
Expired as above. 

#PNA: 
CXR on ___ showing possible RLL opacity, cannot exclude PNA. 
Likely CAP. Howevern, given location and mental status, also 
concern for possible aspiration pneumonitis vs. PNA. Patient 
afebrile, no leukocytosis, however, did develop increased cough 
and sputum production. Repeat CXR with worsening R. effusion. 
Completed treatment with levofloxacin. Expired as above. 

#CAD s/p PCI: 
#Troponinemia: 
NSTEMI w/ PCI to OM1 in ___. Followed by Dr. ___. 
Currently stable. Continued ASA, Eliquis, and  atorvastatin. 
Adjustments to metoprolol as detailed above. Patient was noted 
to have troponemia without ECG changes attributed to demand 
ischemia in setting of atrial fibrillation with RVR. 

#CKD: 
Baseline Cr 1.3-1.5. Remained at baseline throughout admission. 

#HTN: 
BP stable in the 130s-150s/60s-70s throughout admission. 
Continued metoprolol and ISDN. 

#HLD: 
Continued atorvastatin.

#RA: Diagnosed in ___ and main joints involved were bilateral 
hands/wrists, occasional toes/ankles/knees. He had been treated 
with Gold, high dose ASA, plaquenil in the past. Now on 
prednisone, which was continued at home dosing during his 
hospitalization. No concern for adrenal insufficiency requiring 
increased stress dose steroids. 
 
TRANSITIONAL ISSUES:
=================
- Medication changes: switched to metop tartrate 37.5mg q6h. 
- discharged on tube feeds via dobhoff; If no significant 
improvement in mental status over next few weeks, patient and 
family will need to revisit overall goals of care. 
- will require frequent suctioning and chest physical therapy 
for ongoing management of secretions.
- requiring intermittent straight cath for urinary retention; 
continue to bladder scan and monitor PVR. 
- intermittently required diuresis for iatrogenic volume 
overload; discharge weight: ___________*****. 
# Emergency contact: ___  ___, 
___ 
# Code: DNR/DNI

Died with two daughters at bedside on ___.

qafib.question: Does the note describe the patient as having permanent, paroxysmal, or persistent afib?

qprior_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having a stroke or transient ischemic attack?

qarterial_hypertension.question: Does the note describe the patient as having arterial hypertension on treatment (high bp e.g. >140, or HTN)?

qt2d.question: Does the note describe the patient as having Diabetes mellitus (DM1, DM2, T2D, T1DM, T2DM)?

qheart_failure.question: Does the note describe the patient as having heart failure?

qsurgical_valvular_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having valvular disease requiring surgery (stenosis)?

qafib_ablation.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a planned or past ablation procedure for afib?

qbleeding.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a serious bleeding in the past 6 months?

qpeptic_ulcer_disease.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having peptic ulcer disease?

qrecent_stroke.question: Does the note describe the patient as having a stroke during this admission or within the last month? (Answer yes for any recent stroke if the date is unclear)

qhemorrhagic.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever having any hemorrhagic tendencies or blood dyscrasias?

qbipolar.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with bipolar disorder?

qschizophrenia.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with schizophrenia or any schizoaffective disorders?

qmdd.question: Does the note describe the patient as ever being diagnosed with depression or major depressive disorder (MDD)?

qmed_decisions.question: Does the note describe the patient as being unable to make medical decisions? (Answer no unless there is evidence the patient cannot make their own medical decisions).

qchads2.question: What is the highest CHADS2 score mentioned? Answer "NA" if no CHADS2 score is in the note.

qblood_glucose.question: What is the highest blood glucose lab mentioned? Answer "NA" if no blood glucose score is in the note.

qlvef.question: What is the lowest left ventricular ejection (LVEF, ef, ejection fraction) fraction mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no LVEF is in the note, Answer 55 if the lowest value is 55% or greater.

qPLT.question: What is the lowest platelet count (PLT) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no platelet count is available in the note.

qHGB.question: What is the lowest hemoglobin (HGB) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no HGB value is available in the note.

qCREAT.question: What is the higest serum creatinine (Creat) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no creatinine value is available in the note.

qAST.question: What is the higest aspartate aminotransferase level (AST) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no AST value is available in the note.

qBILI.question: What is the higest total bilirubin (TotBili, Bili) mentioned in the note? Answer "NA" if no bilirubin value is available in the note.
